<a href="https://mugsyjeans.com/?utm_source=MorningBrew&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=MorningBrew-11-28-2020" style="border-bottom:none!important;" target="_blank" class=""><img alt="Mugsy" style="width:100%;max-width: 81px; display: inline; vertical-align: middle;" width="81" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL2NvbXBhbnkvbG9nby80MDUvMTYwMjQ4NzE5NC1Mb2dvX011Z3N5X1ByaW1hcnlfTG9nb19FQl9QTkcucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0IjoiY29tZXQtbW9ybmluZ2JyZXciLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ=="></a>
</th>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top:20px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>We hope you enjoyed yesterday’s special newsletter on the coronavirus vaccine supply chain. But that was just Part 1. Today we bring you Part 2, which focuses less on the physical materials and more on the humans.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Let’s set the mood with this passage from <a href="https://www.economist.com/briefing/2020/11/14/an-effective-covid-19-vaccine-is-a-turning-point-in-the-pandemic" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">The Economist</a>: </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>“Deliverance, when it arrives, will come in a small glass vial. First there will be a cool sensation on the upper arm as an alcohol wipe is rubbed across the skin. Then there will be a sharp prick from a needle. Twenty-one days later, the same again. As the nurse drops the used syringe into the bin with a clatter, it will be hard not to wonder how something so small can solve a problem so large.”</em></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PUBLIC HEALTH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/gets-vaccine-first?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Getting in Line for a Vaccine Like
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="A gif of a packed crowd rushing into a store that just opened its doors." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=376 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eoK5GIUKwf0tO/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="A gif of a packed crowd rushing into a store that just opened its doors." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/eoK5GIUKwf0tO/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Reality check: There won't be enough Covid-19 vaccines for everyone for a while. Probably years. Thankfully, the CDC <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/11/05/931844298/first-covid-19-vaccine-doses-to-go-to-health-workers-say-cdc-advisers?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">has some rules</a> so distribution won't look like a run on the <em>Hunger Games</em> cornucopia.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Once a vaccine is approved by the FDA, the CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices will hold an emergency meeting within 48 hours to finalize recommendations around who gets the first shots. That guidance will be given at the national scale, which means state health officials will be left to figure out the nitty-gritty details of where the vials are going.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>As we saw early in the pandemic with various lockdown measures, approaches by states can vary. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Who's first? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The U.S.' ~20 million healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, and support staff, will likely be top priority. Three other groups are widely considered to be especially vulnerable to the coronavirus: </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The elderly (about 50 million Americans ages 65+)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>People with underlying conditions (80–100 million)</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Essential workers (40–60 million)</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That's a lot of millions, and definitely more than we'll have vaccines for at first. Even people who qualify for priority vaccination will contend with limited supply.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Some public health experts have also <a href="https://www.statnews.com/2020/11/09/health-experts-want-to-prioritize-people-of-color-for-covid19-vaccine-but-how-should-it-be-done/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">argued for</a> early vaccinations for racial and ethnic minorities, who've experienced higher rates of coronavirus infection and death.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">And the children? </strong>Pharmaceuticals are, for good reason, not tested on kids first, and it'll <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/next-hunt-covid-19-vaccine-testing-shots-kids-n1244205?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">take longer</a> to get a vaccine approved for the youths. Only a few companies, including Pfizer, have started pediatric trials.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Other factors to consider</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">#1: Different vaccines have different logistical challenges and health considerations</strong>, which could affect who gets what when. Some vaccines may be better suited for the elderly, people with heart conditions, or pregnant women. Single-dose vaccines and ones that don't require ultra-cold storage can reach rural communities more easily. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">#2: Is the goal to limit </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>spread</em></strong><strong style="color:#000"> or </strong><strong style="color:#000"><em>deaths</em></strong><strong style="color:#000">? </strong>Before the swine flu pandemic, the strategy was to vaccinate the most vulnerable first. But in 2009, researchers published a study suggesting a <a href="https://www.cnet.com/how-to/covid-19-vaccines-are-coming-heres-who-will-get-it-first/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">focus on vaccinating the biggest spreaders</a>—in the case of swine flu, children ages 5–19—to protect everyone else. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It helped, and now CDC guidance advises annual flu shots for kids six months and older.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">#3: Not everyone will get a vaccine.</strong> In the last decade, the U.S. has never vaccinated more than half of adults for the flu, and vaccination rates for Black, Latinx, and high-risk adults trend lower. </p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/covax-initiative-seeks-equitable-access-covid-vaccines?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Once We Have a Vaccine...Will We Share It?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you thought state bidding wars for ventilators were ruthless, wait until you learn about the global competition for coronavirus vaccines. The Duke Global Health Institute <a href="https://launchandscalefaster.org/COVID-19?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">estimates</a> 9.6 billion doses are already reserved by individual countries, without any vaccines having reached the market yet. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The early leaders? </strong><a href="https://www.axios.com/how-long-countries-will-wait-for-covid-vaccine-c3106aaf-6ca8-4c7f-af89-ac9b347b25a6.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Wealthier countries</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The U.S., UK, EU, Canada, and Japan have secured 1.1 billion shots of Pfizer's vaccine, roughly 85% of planned production through 2021. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Moderna's first 20 million doses will head to the U.S., which has a contract for 100 million. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Governments were hedging bets by investing in multiple vaccine candidates. But some have struck enough deals that, if multiple vaccines get regulatory approval, they could control a big chunk of supply. For instance, Canada could end up with enough doses to <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-vaccines-covax/exclusive-canada-in-talks-to-donate-extra-covid-19-vaccine-shots-to-poorer-countries-sources-idUSL1N2I42QH?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">vaccinate</a> its population 5x over. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMjI2L2Vjb25vbWlzdF92YWNjaW5lX2dyYXBoaWMucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Economist</em> </small></p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">That's a bit lopsided</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Which is where Covax comes in. This WHO-led initiative is working to ensure equitable vaccine access across the world. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How it works:</strong> There are 184 countries participating, with wealthier countries subsidizing vaccine access for 92 lower- and middle-income ones, particularly across Africa and South and Southeast Asia. The goal is to raise $5 billion and provide 2 billion doses by the end of 2021.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>So far, Covax has secured 700 million doses and $2 billion in funding.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The U.S. is not currently participating; President-elect Joe Biden hasn't said whether his administration will join.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Pharma companies AstraZeneca, Johnson & Johnson, Novavax, and Sanofi plan to produce 3 billion doses for developing countries—some through Covax. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The Duke Global Health Institute thinks it'll take until 2024 for vaccines to reach the entire population. In that time, vaccines could be a new front in geopolitics.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
POLL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/americans-divided-covid19-vaccine?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Prick Me With Your Best Shot
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Shot" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/s3Klt17UqDYyI/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Shot" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/s3Klt17UqDYyI/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Or don't. In a Gallup poll this month, 42% of U.S. adults said they <a href="https://news.gallup.com/poll/325208/americans-willing-covid-vaccine.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">would not</a> get an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine. That's down from a peak of 50% in September, but remains a concerning number for public health officials who want to get Covid-19 under control.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">There are several reasons why the public's confidence is cracking harder than an iPhone screen on concrete.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">37% </strong></span><span>of respondents who said they wouldn't get vaccinated are worried about a rushed timeline.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">26%</strong></span><span> want to wait until they confirm it's safe.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">12% </strong></span><span>don't trust vaccines generally. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That's despite nine pharmaceutical companies, including frontrunners Moderna and Pfizer, <a href="https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/09/08/910671322/9-drugmakers-sign-safety-pledge-in-race-to-develop-covid-19-vaccine?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pledging to hold</a> their products to "high ethical standards and sound scientific principles."</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Dr. Fauci has also tried </span><span><a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/will-covid-vaccine-be-safe-what-scientists-want-see-n1248466?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reassuring</a></span><span> the public that the process "did not compromise at all safety nor did it compromise scientific integrity."</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> At the very end of the Covid-19 vaccine's supply chain are injectees, and the WHO <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/29/who-warns-that-waiting-to-achieve-herd-immunity-to-the-coronavirus-will-kill-a-lot-of-people.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">estimates</a> 60%–80% of them need to be immune for a population to hit herd immunity. Establishing public trust in these vaccines will be the next major challenge for health officials. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HUMAN RESOURCES
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/vaccination-workplace-employers-advised-strongly-encourage?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Your Boss Really, Really Thinks You Should Get Vaccinated
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For U.S. businesses that have been WFH since March, the recent positive developments around vaccine trials landed as an opportunity to get the gang back together. Employers could simply ask all of their employees to get vaccinated, return to the office, and bid adieu to Zoom's 40-minute cutoff forever. But can employers legally require their workers to get vaccines? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Short answer: Yes.* </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">*There <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/16/success/employer-require-covid-vaccination/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">are exceptions</a> for people with disabilities or those with "sincerely held" religious beliefs against vaccination. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Labor and employment attorney Michael Roche </span><span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/can-employers-make-workers-get-coronavirus-vaccination-lawyers-covid-mandatory-2020-11?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told</a></span><span> Business Insider that the safest legal tack is for companies to "strongly encourage employees to get vaccinated." </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>If an employer did require vaccination, it might mean assuming liability for any nasty side effects. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Instead, labor and employment lawyer Jay Rosenlieb advises companies to a) let workers get their shots on company time b) make sure everyone knows senior leadership got poked and c) if the company has a union, ask its leaders to encourage vaccination. </p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CALENDAR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/23/rough-timeline-covid19-immunization-us?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Only Timeline That Matters
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Vaccine clock" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTIxL3ZhY2NpbmVfY2xvY2suanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It's the question we've been asking since March: <em>When will life return to normal</em>? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Finally, a rough timeline is beginning to take shape. Here's the best of all scenarios:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">December 12: </strong>The first immunizations could happen, according to the head of Operation Warp Speed, Dr. Moncef Slaoui. He said he expects about 20 million Americans to get vaccinated during the month.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">January 31, 2021: </strong>About 50 million Americans could be vaccinated by now, and, grouped in with those who've recovered from Covid-19, over 30% of the population <a href="https://twitter.com/ashishkjha/status/1330519144178085899?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">would be immune</a>, per the dean of Brown's public health school, Ashish Jha.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">February/March: </strong>At 30%–40% immunity, according to Jha, the spread will become "meaningfully slower" and infections won't be "self-sustaining." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">April/May: </strong>With a <a href="https://twitter.com/FaceTheNation/status/1330544115788996608?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">widely available vaccine</a>, late spring is when we could see the pandemic truly wind down and life return to what we might call "normal"—but what that even means is still unclear. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>While actually seeing this timeline on paper is enough to make your heart skip a beat, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/covid-vaccine-masks-normal-life/2020/11/20/b4ed16c8-2922-11eb-9b14-ad872157ebc9_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">experts warn</a> the next few months will be challenging for controlling the spread of Covid-19. Masks, social distancing, and other pandemic-era public health measures will be necessary as vaccines are rolled out. </p>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BREW'S BETS
</h3>
</td>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=376 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/eoK5GIUKwf0tO/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"A gif of a packed crowd rushing into a store that just opened its doors.\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/eoK5GIUKwf0tO/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eReality check: There won't be enough Covid-19 vaccines for everyone for a while. Probably years. Thankfully, the CDC \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2020/11/05/931844298/first-covid-19-vaccine-doses-to-go-to-health-workers-say-cdc-advisers?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehas some rules\u003c/a\u003e so distribution won't look like a run on the \u003cem\u003eHunger Games\u003c/em\u003e cornucopia.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOnce a vaccine is approved by the FDA, the CDC's Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices will hold an emergency meeting within 48 hours to finalize recommendations around who gets the first shots. That guidance will be given at the national scale, which means state health officials will be left to figure out the nitty-gritty details of where the vials are going.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAs we saw early in the pandemic with various lockdown measures, approaches by states can vary. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWho's first? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe U.S.' ~20 million healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, and support staff, will likely be top priority. Three other groups are widely considered to be especially vulnerable to the coronavirus: \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe elderly (about 50 million Americans ages 65+)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople with underlying conditions (80–100 million)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eEssential workers (40–60 million)\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat's a lot of millions, and definitely more than we'll have vaccines for at first. Even people who qualify for priority vaccination will contend with limited supply.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSome public health experts have also \u003ca href=\"https://www.statnews.com/2020/11/09/health-experts-want-to-prioritize-people-of-color-for-covid19-vaccine-but-how-should-it-be-done/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eargued for\u003c/a\u003e early vaccinations for racial and ethnic minorities, who've experienced higher rates of coronavirus infection and death.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnd the children? \u003c/strong\u003ePharmaceuticals are, for good reason, not tested on kids first, and it'll \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/next-hunt-covid-19-vaccine-testing-shots-kids-n1244205?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etake longer\u003c/a\u003e to get a vaccine approved for the youths. Only a few companies, including Pfizer, have started pediatric trials.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOther factors to consider\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e#1: Different vaccines have different logistical challenges and health considerations\u003c/strong\u003e, which could affect who gets what when. Some vaccines may be better suited for the elderly, people with heart conditions, or pregnant women. Single-dose vaccines and ones that don't require ultra-cold storage can reach rural communities more easily. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e#2: Is the goal to limit \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003cem\u003espread\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e or \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003cem\u003edeaths\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e? \u003c/strong\u003eBefore the swine flu pandemic, the strategy was to vaccinate the most vulnerable first. But in 2009, researchers published a study suggesting a \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/how-to/covid-19-vaccines-are-coming-heres-who-will-get-it-first/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003efocus on vaccinating the biggest spreaders\u003c/a\u003e—in the case of swine flu, children ages 5–19—to protect everyone else. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt helped, and now CDC guidance advises annual flu shots for kids six months and older.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e#3: Not everyone will get a vaccine.\u003c/strong\u003e In the last decade, the U.S. has never vaccinated more than half of adults for the flu, and vaccination rates for Black, Latinx, and high-risk adults trend lower. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nGEOPOLITICS\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/24/covax-initiative-seeks-equitable-access-covid-vaccines?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nOnce We Have a Vaccine...Will We Share It?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you thought state bidding wars for ventilators were ruthless, wait until you learn about the global competition for coronavirus vaccines. The Duke Global Health Institute \u003ca href=\"https://launchandscalefaster.org/COVID-19?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eestimates\u003c/a\u003e 9.6 billion doses are already reserved by individual countries, without any vaccines having reached the market yet. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe early leaders? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/how-long-countries-will-wait-for-covid-vaccine-c3106aaf-6ca8-4c7f-af89-ac9b347b25a6.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWealthier countries\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe U.S., UK, EU, Canada, and Japan have secured 1.1 billion shots of Pfizer's vaccine, roughly 85% of planned production through 2021. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eModerna's first 20 million doses will head to the U.S., which has a contract for 100 million. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGovernments were hedging bets by investing in multiple vaccine candidates. But some have struck enough deals that, if multiple vaccines get regulatory approval, they could control a big chunk of supply. For instance, Canada could end up with enough doses to \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-vaccines-covax/exclusive-canada-in-talks-to-donate-extra-covid-19-vaccine-shots-to-poorer-countries-sources-idUSL1N2I42QH?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003evaccinate\u003c/a\u003e its population 5x over. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMjI2L2Vjb25vbWlzdF92YWNjaW5lX2dyYXBoaWMucG5nIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIn0=\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"640\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;\" alt=\"\" data-reactroot=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e \u003cem\u003eEconomist\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/small\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThat's a bit lopsided\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhich is where Covax comes in. This WHO-led initiative is working to ensure equitable vaccine access across the world. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow it works:\u003c/strong\u003e There are 184 countries participating, with wealthier countries subsidizing vaccine access for 92 lower- and middle-income ones, particularly across Africa and South and Southeast Asia. The goal is to raise $5 billion and provide 2 billion doses by the end of 2021.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSo far, Covax has secured 700 million doses and $2 billion in funding.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe U.S. is not currently participating; President-elect Joe Biden hasn't said whether his administration will join.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePharma companies AstraZeneca, Johnson \u0026 Johnson, Novavax, and Sanofi plan to produce 3 billion doses for developing countries—some through Covax. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Duke Global Health Institute thinks it'll take until 2024 for vaccines to reach the entire population. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOr don't. In a Gallup poll this month, 42% of U.S. adults said they \u003ca href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/325208/americans-willing-covid-vaccine.aspx?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewould not\u003c/a\u003e get an FDA-approved coronavirus vaccine. That's down from a peak of 50% in September, but remains a concerning number for public health officials who want to get Covid-19 under control.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThere are several reasons why the public's confidence is cracking harder than an iPhone screen on concrete.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e37% \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eof respondents who said they wouldn't get vaccinated are worried about a rushed timeline.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e26%\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e want to wait until they confirm it's safe.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e12% \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003edon't trust vaccines generally. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat's despite nine pharmaceutical companies, including frontrunners Moderna and Pfizer, \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/09/08/910671322/9-drugmakers-sign-safety-pledge-in-race-to-develop-covid-19-vaccine?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epledging to hold\u003c/a\u003e their products to \"high ethical standards and sound scientific principles.\"\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eDr. Fauci has also tried \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/will-covid-vaccine-be-safe-what-scientists-want-see-n1248466?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereassuring\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e the public that the process \"did not compromise at all safety nor did it compromise scientific integrity.\"\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e At the very end of the Covid-19 vaccine's supply chain are injectees, and the WHO \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/29/who-warns-that-waiting-to-achieve-herd-immunity-to-the-coronavirus-will-kill-a-lot-of-people.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eestimates\u003c/a\u003e 60%–80% of them need to be immune for a population to hit herd immunity. style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nYour Boss Really, Really Thinks You Should Get Vaccinated\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor U.S. businesses that have been WFH since March, the recent positive developments around vaccine trials landed as an opportunity to get the gang back together. Employers could simply ask all of their employees to get vaccinated, return to the office, and bid adieu to Zoom's 40-minute cutoff forever. But can employers legally require their workers to get vaccines? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eShort answer: Yes.* \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e*There \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/16/success/employer-require-covid-vaccination/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eare exceptions\u003c/a\u003e for people with disabilities or those with \"sincerely held\" religious beliefs against vaccination. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLabor and employment attorney Michael Roche \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/can-employers-make-workers-get-coronavirus-vaccination-lawyers-covid-mandatory-2020-11?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Business Insider that the safest legal tack is for companies to \"strongly encourage employees to get vaccinated.\" \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIf an employer did require vaccination, it might mean assuming liability for any nasty side effects. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInstead, labor and employment lawyer Jay Rosenlieb advises companies to a) let workers get their shots on company time b) make sure everyone knows senior leadership got poked and c) if the company has a union, ask its leaders to encourage vaccination. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt's the question we've been asking since March: \u003cem\u003eWhen will life return to normal\u003c/em\u003e? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFinally, a rough timeline is beginning to take shape. Here's the best of all scenarios:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eDecember 12: \u003c/strong\u003eThe first immunizations could happen, according to the head of Operation Warp Speed, Dr. Moncef Slaoui. He said he expects about 20 million Americans to get vaccinated during the month.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eJanuary 31, 2021: \u003c/strong\u003eAbout 50 million Americans could be vaccinated by now, and, grouped in with those who've recovered from Covid-19, over 30% of the population \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/ashishkjha/status/1330519144178085899?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewould be immune\u003c/a\u003e, per the dean of Brown's public health school, Ashish Jha.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFebruary/March: \u003c/strong\u003eAt 30%–40% immunity, according to Jha, the spread will become \"meaningfully slower\" and infections won't be \"self-sustaining.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eApril/May: \u003c/strong\u003eWith a \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/FaceTheNation/status/1330544115788996608?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewidely available vaccine\u003c/a\u003e, late spring is when we could see the pandemic truly wind down and life return to what we might call \"normal\"—but what that even means is still unclear. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile actually seeing this timeline on paper is enough to make your heart skip a beat, \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/health/covid-vaccine-masks-normal-life/2020/11/20/b4ed16c8-2922-11eb-9b14-ad872157ebc9_story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexperts warn\u003c/a\u003e the next few months will be challenging for controlling the spread of Covid-19.
